abstract.p: Richard Ney Jr letter on Nov 18 article on difficulty poor people without cars face getting to jobs (S)

block.p: ''Poor Without Cars Find Trek to Work Is Now a Job''(front page, Nov. 18) neglects to mention bicycles as a viable form of transportation. In fact, the article denigrates bicycles by citing only the hapless dishwashers riding along Main Street in Mount Kisco, N.Y. on their ''rusty bicycles.''

''Poor Without Cars Find Trek to Work Is Now a Job''(front page, Nov. 18) neglects to mention bicycles as a viable form of transportation. In fact, the article denigrates bicycles by citing only the hapless dishwashers riding along Main Street in Mount Kisco, N.Y. on their ''rusty bicycles.''

Bicycles are used by millions around the world to commute to work. A 15-mile trip is not very difficult on a well-maintained bicycle, and a cyclist in good shape should be able to commute at least 25 miles each way in all but the worst weather. Well-made commuting bikes can be purchased for a few hundred dollars. Moreover, cycling creates no pollution and provides a good source of exercise.
